content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure shows a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “r, in centimeters.” The heading for row 2 is “f of r, in milligrams per square centimeter.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. r is 0. f of r is 1. Column 2. r is 1. f of r is 2. Column 3. r is 2. f of r is 6. Column 4. r is 2.5. f of r is 10. Column 5. r is 4. f of r is 18." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid solid solid none" frame="solid" rowlines="solid none"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>r</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(centimeters)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(milligrams per square centimeter)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>18</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math> The density of a bacteria population in a circular petri dish at a distance <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> centimeters from the center of the dish is given by an increasing, differentiable function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="f of r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in milligrams per square centimeter. Values of <math alttext="f of r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for selected values of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. (a) Use the data in the table to estimate <math alttext="f prime of 2.25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.25</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of your answer in the context of this problem.

However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure shows a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “r, in centimeters.” The heading for row 2 is “f of r, in milligrams per square centimeter.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. r is 0. f of r is 1. Column 2. r is 1. f of r is 2. Column 3. r is 2. f of r is 6. Column 4. r is 2.5. f of r is 10. Column 5. r is 4. f of r is 18." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid solid solid none" frame="solid" rowlines="solid none"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>r</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(centimeters)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(milligrams per square centimeter)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>18</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math> The density of a bacteria population in a circular petri dish at a distance <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> centimeters from the center of the dish is given by an increasing, differentiable function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="f of r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in milligrams per square centimeter. Values of <math alttext="f of r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for selected values of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. (a) Use the data in the table to estimate <math alttext="f prime of 2.25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.25</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of your answer in the context of this problem.

(b) The total mass, in milligrams, of bacteria in the petri dish is given by the integral expression <math alttext="2 pi times, the integral from, 0 to 4, of, r times, f of r, d r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.15em"></mspace><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>r</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.15em"></mspace><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>. Approximate the value of <math alttext="2 pi times, the integral from, 0 to 4, of, r times, f of r, d r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.15em"></mspace><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>r</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.15em"></mspace><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> using a right Riemann sum with the four subintervals indicated by the data in the table.
(c) Is the approximation found in part (b) an overestimate or underestimate of the total mass of bacteria in the petri dish? Explain your reasoning.

(d) The density of bacteria in the petri dish, for <math alttext="1 less than or equal to r, less than or equal to 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is modeled by the function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined by <math alttext="g of r, equals, 2 minus, 16 times, open parenthesis, the cosine of, open parenthesis, 1.57 times the square root of r, close parenthesis, close parenthesis, cubed" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>16</mn><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.57</mn><msqrt><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. For what value of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="1 less than k, less than 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo><</mo><mi>k</mi><mo><</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is <math alttext="g of k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> equal to the average value of <math alttext="g of r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> on the interval <math alttext="1 less than or equal to r, less than or equal to 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 2.3: Estimating Derivatives of a Function at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
